webTitle: JP Morgan Chase hires 3,000 new staff in its compliance department

fields.standfirst: Move is latest attempt to prepare market for outcome of negotiations over $770m settlement for 'London Whale'
fields.body:
The US banking group JP Morgan Chase has employed an extra 3,000 staff in its compliance department during 2013 in its latest attempt to prepare the market for the outcome of negotiations over a $770m (£440m) settlement with regulators over the "London Whale" trading incident.

US prosecutors have already accused the bank of a cultural breakdown because of the $6bn losses incurred during activities that became known as the London Whale owing to the scale of the trading positions.

In a message to all the bank's staff, the chief executive, Jamie Dimon, said: "Adjusting to the new regulatory environment will require an enormous amount of time, effort and resources. We fully intend to follow the letter and spirit of every rule and requirement."

He said that since 2012 more than 4,000 extra staff had been assigned to control areas such as risk, compliance, legal and finance and that 3,000 of those had been hired this year. An extra $1bn was being spent on controls and 500 "dedicated professionals and several thousand others" were helping the bank submit its regulatory files on capital to US regulators. Staff had undergone 750,000 hours of training on compliance issues.

Anti-money laundering (AML) laws have also been a focus of the bank which, Dimon, said was "deploying unprecedented resources, dedicating senior managerial time and prioritising efforts to build and maintain an industry-leading AML programme".

He has already announced plans to pull out of risky areas such as student lending origination and most of the physical commodities sales and trading business. The bank is no longer going to sell identity-theft protection and credit insurance to customers and is conducting an in-depth review of the overseas correspondent banking business.

webTitle: Letters: The economic reality is that no one is as wealthy as they pretend

fields.body:
Larry Elliott gives a coherent summary of the post-crash economic hiatus (Lehman Brothers collapse, 14 September). I don't do economics; I do double-entry bookkeeping. In bookkeeping terms, the world economy has more debt than there is value-added labour to repay said debt. It follows that a significant proportion of debt is going to be written off, cancelled or forgiven. The international economy is still in the process of deciding who precisely stands the loss. Creditors remain reluctant to surrender the gains accumulated during the boom. Governments are reluctant to make any decision that will upset everybody. The public simply wants to put a card in a machine and be sure some money will come out. Consequently, debt remains the can that gets kicked down the road.

Ultimately, debt will be repaid from current earnings and associated money flows. In practice, living standards will come down, prices will increase, the quality of services will be eroded, provision priced to restrict utilisation, and pension income will become increasingly problematic. Existing debt will be serviced, forgiven or devalued over an extended period and, consequently, real economic growth will be compromised. In the short term, weak governments will resort to increasing debt to disguise the fact that their economic policies are the same as those of the opposition, just looked at from the opposite direction. There seems to be no politician anywhere in the world big enough to address the fundamental issue: no one is as wealthy as they pretend.
Martin London
Henllan, Denbighshire

• Phillip Inman (Inflation is no longer the Bank's watchword, 16 September) mentions in four places the importance of wages and concludes: "Only higher wages can cure the problem and they don't look like making an appearance any time soon." Is this not the nub of the crisis? The share of wages in national output has declined over the past 30 years and the value of wages has also gone down as price rises have outstripped wage rises. In the absence of real wage rises, consumer demand can only increase to boost economic recovery by increasing borrowing and therefore debt levels.

If wages were to increase in the private sector, that would lead to a corresponding decrease in profits and therefore an increase in prices to restore profit levels. Real demand would fall again. If wages were to increase in the public sector, that would increase the government deficit and would lead to further cuts in services, as well as health and education provision. So if wage increases are the answer, to boost demand, how can wages be increased given the present economic crisis?
Darrall Cozens
Coventry

• You say "Nick Clegg and his supporters wished to prove the pain of austerity has been worth it, and to take some political credit for economic recovery" (Editorial, 17 September). This seems to assume that the "recovery" is the result of the coalition's austerity policy, whereas my impression is that their policy actually hampered recovery. The ensuing pain was chiefly the lot of the poorest and most vulnerable; the more affluent do not appear to have suffered unduly. It seems improbable that those who really bear the suffering would find it was worth the pain.
Francis Westoby
Hitchin, Hertfordshire

webTitle: Slumping car sales underline fragility of eurozone economy

fields.standfirst: The UK is the only major European market to record more new passenger car registrations in 2013 than last year
fields.body:
Slumping car sales across the EU in August have underlined the fragility of the eurozone economy, with the cumulative figures for the year to date at a record low.

The UK remained the only major European market to record more new passenger car registrations in 2013 than last year, with 10.9% more sales this August than last.

Across the EU, sales dropped to 653,872 vehicles in August – traditionally a slow month but a figure that still remains 5% lower than in 2012. For 2013 so far, the total stands at just 7,841,596 – the lowest figure since the European Automobile Manufacturers' Association (ACEA) started compiling them in 1990.

After a slight rise in July, the trend continued downwards outside the UK, with what is set to be a sixth straight year of falling sales. Sales slid further in France, Italy and Germany. In Cyprus sales this year are down 40%. ACEA said: "The downturn prevailed across significant markets."

The PSA Group, manufacturer of Peugeot and Citroën cars, continued to lose ground to rivals, with an 18% drop in registrations, while market leader Volkswagen Group's sales fell 11% in August. VW-brand vehicles alone were down 17.3% year on year – a statistic the German manufacturer partly attributed to freak weather that damaged thousands of vehicles ahead of delivery.

Despite the downward trend, analysts believe the picture could soon improve for car manufacturers. Mark Fulthorpe, an automotive analyst at IHS, said: "The general sense we get is that we are now bumping along the bottom. At least in the car market, the rate of decline has slowed.

"There have been some positive developments in France and Germany in recent months, but not enough to offset problems in the periphery – but we may get a more neutral picture ahead."

He pointed to the experience of Britain and the US to argue that car sales in Europe could pick up before a full economic recovery. "The age of vehicles on the road is increasing, and servicing costs and repair costs for older vehicles will give many drivers reason for a newer car when consumer confidence returns at all.

"That has been the impetus for the turnaround we've seen in the American market, where many purchases were deferred in the darkest days of the crisis."

He added: "It's only in last few weeks that commentators in the UK have really thought that the economy has turned, but you can see from the last year's figures that people were already making those big-ticket purchases here."

The UK has now seen 18 months of consecutive rises, with the market for new cars in August up to 65,937 units. Although September's figures will be more significant, the summer continued the trend of double-digit rises.

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders ascribed the growth to increasingly confident consumers being offered attractive terms, including a surge in sales of alternative fuel cars. Mike Hawes, SMMT's chief executive said: "Buyers are clearly capitalising on attractive deals and new technologies against a backdrop of increasing economic confidence."

webTitle: Hovis staff in Wigan to strike for third week over zero-hours agency staff

fields.standfirst: Owner Premier Foods says it wants to arbitrate using Acas but only when the BFAWU union has called off its action
fields.body:
Hovis staff are planning a third week of strikes and a "day of action" backed by several unions after failing to reach agreement over use of agency staff on zero-hours contracts.

The action in Wigan comes after three people were arrested on Monday at a demonstration outside the bakery – one of 10 Hovis sites in the UK – where agency workers were introduced this year following job and pay cuts.

The Bakers Food & Allied Workers Union (BFAWU), which represents 230 of the 357 employees at the Wigan bakery, is campaigning against use of the agency staff whose zero-hour contracts do not specify set working hours and give limited guarantees on conditions.

Ronnie Draper, the union's general secretary, said he had not heard from Hovis's owner, Premier Foods, which is using managers from other factories to keep production going in Wigan during the strikes. "They are totally intransigent as far as agency labour goes," he said.

Premier said it wanted to hold talks with the arbitration service Acas to resolve a "breakdown in trust" in Wigan but would not do so until the union called off strike action. A spokesman said it would use agency labour only in certain circumstances including holiday and sickness cover, adding: "We have the right to do so in all our other bakeries with the support of the union."

But Draper said using agency staff to cover holidays meant they would be present on a virtually constant basis. He added: "I spoke at many meetings at the TUC conference last week and all the big unions are going to support those in Wigan. This is a major issue for the trade union movement. If Hovis gets away with it people will try to do the same elsewhere." He said he hoped the stance being taken in Wigan would "inspire others".

Other unions including Unite and Unison are expected to back a day of action in Wigan on 28 September, which follows a similar event attended by up to 400 people on 14 September.

webTitle: Help to Buy is just a bad idea, plain and simple | Nils Pratley

fields.bodyText: London's housing market does not need stimulating. That much should be clear from Tuesday's figures from the Office for National Statistics showing house prices in the capital rising at almost 10% at a time when general inflation, as measured by the consumer prices index, is 2.7%. In these circumstances it would be madness for the state to subsidise mortgages by giving partial guarantees to lenders, which is how the second stage of Help to Buy is meant to work from January. The government would be inviting lop-sided speculation and yet another bubble. The thin justification for the scheme is that housebuilders will be encouraged to build – but, come on, when prices are rising at 10% the incentive to build on every scrap of land with planning permission is lit in neon. The case for proceeding with Help to Buy outside the capital is clearly stronger. And business secretary Vince Cable has hinted at two ways in which this could be done: the scheme could be restricted to homes outside London and the south-east; alternatively, the £600,000 cap on qualifying purchases could be lowered. Would that be a useful and pragmatic compromise? Well, regional tailoring would be an improvement. But, no, Help to Buy is just a bad idea, plain and simple. The regional disparities are interesting but the overall picture in the UK is that house prices are within a whisker of their 2008 peak. But affordability – as measured by earnings-to-house-price ratios – is still extremely stretched by historical standards. Artificially pushing prices higher now risks a painful crash when interest rates have to rise. If the government wants to interfere, it should concentrate on finding direct ways to build more homes – Help to Buy is a roundabout method that risks too many bad consequences.

webTitle: Debenhams boss issues housing market warning as stores enjoy rise in sales

fields.standfirst: Michael Sharp welcomes signs of economic recovery but echoes house price  concerns  voiced by Next boss Simon Wolfson
fields.body:
The housing market needs "careful management" to avoid pumping up prices, which would put consumers under renewed pressure, the chief executive of Debenhams has warned.

Michael Sharp's concerns echo those of Simon Wolfson, the boss of fashion and homewares chain Next, who said last week that house price rises would give the economy "a problem", because they were unsustainable.

The department store group boss welcomed signs of recovery in the economy though said that was unlikely to feed through to better consumer sentiment in the short or medium term as inflation is "still here and well ahead of wage growth". Sentiment was still "bumping along the bottom," as shoppers' disposable income was still less than this time last year.

He added: "The housing market needs careful management. We don't want to go back to the bad old days where the housing market runs away with itself, and people get engrossed in high levels of debt."

Despite Sharp's relatively gloomy outlook, shares in Debenhams rose 1.8p to 105p as the department store group revealed a better than expected 1.9% rise in underlying sales in the 10 weeks to the end of August accompanied by a rise in profit margins. Sharp said growth had come via the internet, where sales rose 46.2% for the year while high street sales continued to fall back once new store openings had been stripped out.

Sharp conceded that Debenhams had been helped by the warm weather in July and August, which helped it to clear summer stock with less need for discounting. However, he said the retailer had also taken market share in all its main categories, such as womenswear and footwear, as its "designers" ranges, such as Butterfly by Matthew Williamson, continued to prove popular. "We are back on track," he said.

Like Next and Primark, Debenhams continues to open new stores with four planned in the next year after two openings in the past 12 months. Sharp said that while sales were falling in the stores, all remained profitable and were an important point of contact for online shoppers, who liked to pick up goods they had ordered online at their nearest high street.

Given the changing role of physical stores and rising influence of the internet, Sharp added his voice to a chorus of retailers large and small calling for a change to the business rates system, a tax based on property. "The current rating system is not fit for purpose and antiquated," he said. "It needs to be fundamentally reviewed. It's not about tweaking around the edges."

webTitle: Lloyds boss told Osborne to press on with the sale – and he did

fields.standfirst: With the bailed-out bank back in profit, the chancellor can even claim a £60m profit on the sale of 15% of the taxpayer's stake
fields.body:
Get on with it. That was the clear message sent to the chancellor last month by António Horta-Osório, the boss of Lloyds Banking Group.

The bailed-out bank was back in profit and Horta-Osório was talking about paying dividends to shareholders for the first time since the crisis. It was time to start selling down the taxpayer's 39% stake.

On Tuesday his wish was granted, the first tranche of shares was sold and the government was handed a £60m profit five years to the day since Lloyds stepped in to rescue the near-bankrupt HBOS.

In reality, preparations for a sale were under way before Horta-Osório urged the government to act. In March, the government linked his bonus to a sale of the shares and in his June Mansion House speech, George Osborne signalled a selloff was being considered.

UK Financial Investments, the body that oversees the government's bank stakes, was scrutinising the Lloyds share price throughout August. Meanwhile City brokers were calling clients around the world – investment houses working on behalf of pension funds and life insurers – to gauge their interest.

On Monday afternoon the sales teams at UBS, Bank of America Merrill Lynch and JP Morgan, which has been advising UKFI, sprang into action.

By then a number of hurdles had been cleared. Last week the Competition Commission cleared the Lloyds selloff of its TSB brand and 631 branches with only a few small caveats. Then on Monday markets were buoyed by reports that hawkish Larry Summers was no longer in the running to head the US Federal Reserve.

Robin Budenberg, the outgoing chairman of UKFI, formally wrote to Osborne that day to tell him it was the "right moment to sell for taxpayers". The chancellor was also advised by Sir Nick Macpherson, the permanent secretary, that it was time to press the button. At the Liberal Democrats' conference in Glasgow, Danny Alexander, the most senior Lib Dem in the Treasury, was told of the decision to sell, which had been taken by UKFI in a call at 4.15pm.

At 4.45pm, UKFI announced to the stock exchange that the deal was to be done, sparking discussions about whether the 75p sale price – above the 73.6p break-even price – was good value. Small investors are expected to be offered shares in the next Lloyds sell-off and the remaining 32.7% stake could be sold before the election.

Ian Gordon, banks analyst at Investec, said the timing was "impeccable" while Shailesh Raikundlia, analyst at Espirito Santo, thought the size of the share sale was less ambitious than expected but added: "It does start the ball rolling for the government to exit from its bank holdings."

The share price reaction – they closed at 74.65p – suggests it was a good call. "If it had popped higher we'd have done it too cheaply," one banker said. However, only the share price movement in coming months will determine if the price was right.

Certainly not everyone was instantly impressed: officials at the Unite union – who have watched Lloyds shed 45,000 jobs – accused the government of a fire sale while parliament is recess. National officer Dominic Hook said: "It raises suspicions that the chancellor is playing fast and loose with the taxpayers' money for his own short-term political purposes."

According to Unite, if the original investment price of 73.6p is adjusted for inflation, the break-even price would be near 93p and the sale has created a £770m loss rather than the £60m profit the government claims.

At the Liberal Democrats' conference in Glasgow, Danny Alexander, the most senior Lib Dem in the Treasury, was told of the decision to sell, which had been taken by UKFI in a call at 4.15pm. At 4.45pm, UKFI announced to the stock exchange that the deal was to be done, sparking discussions about whether the 75p sale price – above the 73.6p break-even price – was good value. Small investors are expected to be offered shares in the next Lloyds sell-off and the remaining 32.7% stake could be sold before the election. Ian Gordon, banks analyst at Investec, said the timing was "impeccable" while Shailesh Raikundlia, analyst at Espirito Santo, thought the size of the share sale was less ambitious than expected but added: "It does start the ball rolling for the government to exit from its bank holdings." The share price reaction – they closed at 74.65p – suggests it was a good call. "If it had popped higher we'd have done it too cheaply," one banker said. However, only the share price movement in coming months will determine if the price was right. Certainly not everyone was instantly impressed: officials at the Unite union – who have watched Lloyds shed 45,000 jobs – accused the government of a fire sale while parliament is recess. National officer Dominic Hook said: "It raises suspicions that the chancellor is playing fast and loose with the taxpayers' money for his own short-term political purposes." According to Unite, if the original investment price of 73.6p is adjusted for inflation, the break-even price would be near 93p and the sale has created a £770m loss rather than the £60m profit the government claims.
fields.headline: Lloyds boss told Osborne to press on with the sale – and he did

webTitle: New census bureau survey: women earn $11,500 less than men annually

fields.standfirst: At the same time, almost half of US households with children are financially headed by women – and race intensifies the disparity
fields.body:
Women in full-time work earned an average of $11,500 less than their male counterparts in 2012, according to new data released Tuesday from the US census bureau's annual survey.

According to the new survey data, women with full-time, year-round jobs were paid just 77¢ for every dollar paid to men who hold full-time, year-round jobs. The difference in median wages means women earn $11,500 less than men.

Race intensified the wage disparity. African American women were paid 69¢ for every dollar paid to all men, and 64¢ for every dollar paid to white, non-Hispanic men. Latinas were paid 58¢ for every dollar paid to all men, and 54¢ for every dollar paid to white, non-Hispanic men.

The number of men working full time increased by 1m, while it was unchanged for women. Nationally the census said median income dropped from $51,100 to $51,017, a change the bureau described as statistically insignificant. The poverty rate, at 15%, was unchanged for the second consecutive year.

Four in 10 US households with children under age 18 now include a mother who is either the sole or primary earner for her family, according to a Pew Research Center study released in May. The figure is the highest on record and has grown steadily throughout the recession.

Barack Obama has pushed to address the gender gap but the Paycheck Fairness Act has stalled in Congress amid Republican opposition. In June, marking the 50th anniversary of the Equal Pay Act, Obama called again for Congress to pass the paycheck fairness act and raise the minimum wage. "I want every child to grow up knowing that a woman's hard work is valued and rewarded just as much as any man's. So together, let's create a future where our daughters' work is valued as much as our sons'," he said.

According to the National Partnership for Women & Families, the gender gap has remained largely unchanged for 11 years. Women have been paid 77¢ for every dollar paid to men since 2002, with two minor exceptions: in 2003, women were paid 76¢ for every dollar paid to men, and in 2007, women were paid 78¢ for every dollar.

Debra Ness, president of the National Partnership for Women & Families, said: "The persistence of the gender-based wage gap is a blot on our nation's commitment to civil rights and equal opportunity. These new data should give Congress and the administration even more reason to make addressing it a priority. In doing so, both have the opportunity to set an example for employers, and to demonstrate a true commitment to improving the well-being of America's families."

webTitle: Housebuilders report booming business

fields.standfirst: Galliford Try and Crest Nicholson helped by government support for housing market and rise in consumer confidence
fields.body:
Galliford Try and Crest Nicholson have become the latest housebuilders to report booming business helped by government support for the housing market and a rise in consumer confidence.

Galliford Try, which also has a construction business, reported record full-year profits, while Crest Nicholson said demand was so strong that its suppliers were struggling to keep up.

It comes amid growing concern that the government's Help to Buy scheme is creating a new house price bubble. The business secretary, Vince Cable, and former Bank of England governor Sir Mervyn King have been among those to voice concern.

Pre-tax profits rose 17% to £74.1m at Galliford Try in the year to 30 June, boosted by Help to Buy, improved market sentiment, higher margins, and investment in high return land opportunities, particularly in the south and south-east of England.

Record profits were achieved despite a fall in the number of homes completed to 2,932 from 3,039, which the company said was the result of its focus on sites with better returns.

Chief executive Greg Fitzgerald said the group was "well positioned" to capitalise on signs of an improving construction market. Galliford has a record land bank with 11,300 plots and all the land it needs for 2014.

The confident mood was reflected by Stephen Stone, chief executive at fellow FTSE 250 builder Crest Nicholson, who said an increase in reservations confirmed "the strong desire for home ownership that exists in this country".

In a trading update for the period 1 May to 6 September, housing reservations averaged almost 44 a week compared with 25 for the same period in 2012.

Its suppliers, however, were struggling to meet the higher demand. "Higher levels of reservations have brought some initial pressures to bear on elements of our supply chain. As expected, we have seen some cost increases in certain building materials and also some delivery delays," the company said.

Crest said sales had been improving since the beginning of 2013, helped by the Funding for Lending scheme, which was feeding through to lower mortgage rates for borrowers, and the Help to Buy scheme announced in the March budget. Advance sales for 2014 and beyond total £145m, a 92% increase compared with this time last year.

Improved trading was also reflected in fewer cancellations, which averaged 10.5% over the period compared with 15.8% a year earlier.

Crest, which floated in February, said "government efforts to stimulate the housing market" were likely to play a part in good trading conditions "for the next few years".

webTitle: European car sales slump, as Barroso spies Greek recovery - as it happened

fields.bodyText: Time to stop. Here's a reminder of the main events • The slump in Europe's car market continues, with sales falling again in August. Declining demand in key markets such as Germany and France mean 2013 has been the worst year since records began in 1990. • EC president Jose Manuel Barroso has declared that Greece can see better times ahead. Speaking in Brussels alongside Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras, Barroso claimed that the country's recession was nearly over. But there was also no let-up in the pressure for reforms. • As the talks took place, there were fresh protests in Athens. Social service workers and municipal police officers held demonstrations, while doctors began a three-day walkout. A larger strike begins tomorrow. • UK inflation fell. At 2.7%, the consumer prices index showed that prices rose at a slightly slower rate in August. However, new data also showed house prices rising faster, with English prices at a new record high. • The British government hailed the sale of part of its sale in Lloyds Banking Group as a milestone in escaping the financial crisis. The sale, announced last night, made a profit of £60m • Italy's former prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, has delayed the release of a video message outlining his political plans following a conviction for tax fraud. It should be released tomorrow, the same day that a Senate committee is due to decide whether he should be expelled from the upper house of parliament..... • The US Federal Reserve began its two-day monetary policy meeting. Ben Bernanke could announce that the Fed will start tapering its bond-buying programme tomorrow night. Or he might not..... • ....and the uncertainty helped to push shares down in Europe. I'll be back tomorrow for more of the same. Until then, goodnight, and thanks for all the comments. GW One more story to flag up... European Commissioner Olli Rehn told Italian politicians some home truths today, warning that political instability and slow progress on fiscal cutbacks threatens to reignite the crisis. The FT has a good write up: By stepping directly into a fiercely political debate in expressing Brussels’ opposition to Rome’s decision to scrap an unpopular property tax, Olli Rehn, the commissioner for economic and monetary affairs, risks fuelling tensions between the main parties in Italy’s fragile coalition government over its budget for 2014. Mr Rehn reminded a news conference on Tuesday that Italy’s borrowing costs on debt markets had overtaken Spain’s this month for the first time in more than a year. “To my mind this is a warning sign to Italy to ensure political stability and fiscal sustainability,” he commented. European stock markets closed mostly lower, as traders prepared for tomorrow's policy announcement from the Federal Reserve (5.38pm) The only markets to rise were Italy (where Silvio Berlusconi's much-anticipated video message is expected tomorrow), and Greece. Otherwise, it's been quiet. Brenda Kelly of IG sums up the action in London: Lloyds Bank has been the worst casualty, falling 3.3% after the government sold 6% of its stake in the bailed-out bank. Barclays was also under water, with news announcing that it is facing a £50 million fine for breaching market listing rules. The failure to break through yesterday’s highs, despite the UK CPI easing to 2.7% in August as expected, suggests that investors are wary and less inclined to establish new long positions. The profit-taking that we are seeing is an attempt to drain what may be the final dregs of the rally. Since markets are, for the most part, expecting a tapering decision, any delay could be construed as a lack of US Federal Reserve confidence in the US economic recovery and may add some volatility and downside risk for equities. In America, the Federal Reserve has begun its two-day meeting as speculation mounts that chairman Ben Bernanke is preparing to announce cut-backs on the US's $85bn-a-month economic stimulus programme. Tapering could be just around the corner, writes our Wall Street correspondent Dominic Rushe: Bernanke will hold a press conference Wednesday to discuss the Fed's plans. The event comes amid speculation that he will announce his resignation: Bernanke has made clear he will not seek a third term as chairman and Barack Obama is now assessing replacements. The Fed's third round of bond buying, known as quantitative easing, was announced last September and has so far pumped about $800bn into the bond markets in an attempt to kick-start investment and keep interest rates down. In June, Bernanke announced some "tapering" of policy could begin later this year if the economy continued to improve. The Federal Reserve's open markets committee (FOMC), however, is split on QE with some concerned about the unintended consequences of the massive programme. In previous FOMC meetings some members have made clear they want an early end to the programme. More here: Federal Reserve begins two-day meeting as stimulus taper looms Ambrose Evans-Pritchard of the Daily Telegraph has delivered a masterful response to German finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble, which is well worth a read. Writing in the Financial Times today, Schäuble declared that the eurozone economic recovery was well underway, and taunted those who had claimed Europe had lost the plot. The nub of his point is that Europe's policymakers had implemented sensible policies, whose effectiveness was proven in recessions through the ages. Here's a flavour: What is happening turns out to be pretty much what the proponents of Europe’s cool-headed crisis management predicted. The fiscal and structural repair work is paying off, laying the foundations for sustainable growth. This has taken critical observers aback. It should not have, because, in truth, we have seen it all before, many times and in many places. Despite what the critics of the European crisis management would have us believe, we live in the real world, not in a parallel universe where well-established economic principles no longer apply. Further down in the article, Schäuble wins more friends by claiming that Europe's public have been protected from the worst of the storm. The European safety nets have provided a well-calibrated mix of incentives and solidarity to cushion the pain. I"m not completely convinced that those who argued for a change of plan are now lying broken and discredited under the wheels of Europe's revival (tho anyone who insisted the eurozone would break up by now looks a little daft). And over at Telegraph Towers, AEP seems to agree, in a classic column. Again, here's a taste: I apologise for mentioning that unemployment is 27.8% in Greece, 26.3% in Spain, 17.3% in Cyprus, and 16.5% in Portugal, or for pointing that it would be far worse had it not been for a mass exodus of EMU refugees. Nor was is proper to mention that Greek youth unemployment in 62.9%. These are trivial details. I apologise for pointing out that the EU-IMF Troika originally said the Greek economy would contract by 2.6% in 2010 and then recover briskly, when in fact it contracted by roughly 23% from peak-to-trough, and will shrink another 5% this year according to the think-tank IOBE. This slippage is well within the normal margin of error. I apologise for mentioning that the debt trajectories of Spain, Greece, Italy, and Ireland have accelerated upwards under the austerity plans, and therefore that the policy has been self-defeating. It was quite uncalled for to point out that Italy’s debt ratio has jumped to 130% of GDP, or to so suggest that debt cannot keep rising on a contracting nominal GDP bas, and I will wash my mouth with soap if I ever utter the words “denominator effect” again. It is shabby to use such cheap language. My grovelling apology to Herr Schäuble Back in the UK, chancellor George Osborne has been hailing the sale of some of the government's stake in Lloyds. Here's a video clip from earlier today: I'd missed this .... (thanks IfigEusLannuon!) A reminder that my colleagues on GuardianWitness want to hear from people who have splashed out on a new bike this year, following the news that bicycle sales outstripped demand for new cars in Spain in 2012. Just go here to learn more. And here's an example: Talk of 'light at the end of the tunnel' may infuriate Greek citizens struggling to cope with the country's economic plight. Issues such as record unemployment and sliding retail sales are well documented. But government cutbacks are hurting the public in other ways, as Yannis Zabetakis flags up from Athens. He tells me that primary schools are now closing at 13.30pm, rather than 4pm, which is a "massive problems for working parents". He blames cutbacks on teachers, reporting that some schools don't even have enough teachers to cover morning classes. The full text of Jose Manuel Barrosa's comments to Antonis Samaras in Brussels earlier are now online, here. It shows that Barroso twice described Samaras as a "dear friend", congratulating him on saving Greece from crashing out of the euro. Here's the key section about 'light at the end of the tunnel': On the economy now: I want to say that I very much support Greece's efforts in implementing the financial assistance programme. Prime Minister Samaras has once again assured me of his clear commitment to see it through. The Commission continues to believe that this is essential to secure Greece's future growth and jobs, and it is already giving positive results. I really want to congratulate you, Prime Minister, dear friend, for your leadership and determination. I believe it is key for the success of the programme. I know that the Greek citizens are operating in extremely challenging and difficult circumstances, but I believe now we can say there is light at the end of the tunnel. In fact, we expect a gradual return to growth in 2014 after six years of recession; government bond spreads haven fallen markedly since their peak in June 2012; economic sentiment has improved; the current account deficit has fallen over the last three years and Greece's debt-to-GDP ratio is set to start declining next year and fall below 120% by 2021. All these are encouraging signals when you think of the doubts that were expressed some time ago concerning Greece. Barroso also repeated a theme from last week's State of the Union speech -- next year's European Parliament elections, which will be a battleground between eurosceptics and pro-Europeans. In May, people will head to the polls to vote in the European Parliament elections, and it is very important that we make these elections a moment of European democracy. Critics of Europe's handling of the crisis, though, might remind Barroso that technocratic (unelected) leaders briefly ran both Greece and Italy in the last couple of years -- not exactly democracy's finest hour..... The WSJ's Matina Stevis was also at the Barroso-Samaras press conference in Brussels, and reports the key lines: Jose Manuel Barroso also gave Greece the 'hurry-up' on its state asset sales, saying that its privatisation programme needs to be "sped up". The FT's Peter Spiegel reports that prime minister Antonis Samaras nodded at this point. Worth noting that the two men were also all smiles for the cameras before today's press conference: Jose Manuel Barroso and Antonis Samaras are fielding questions on what additional help Greece will need next year when its bailout programme runs out. Barroso tried to duck the question, saying he need to see the verdict of Greece's lenders (who return to Athens next Monday) first. Samaras was merely hopeful that Greece's economy might perform better than some economists fear. The FT's Peter Spiegel has the quotes: Samaras went on to insist that "The sacrifices of the Greek people are producing tangible results," and offered the prospect of the country finally escaping recession during its EU presidency (January-June 2014). Samaras says the answer to Greece's problems is "more growth" (no argument there) and "more Europe" (which might be more controversial). Now Greek PM Antonis Samaras is speaking in Brussels, declaring that the country's' recession is nearly over. Samaras also said Greece is close to posting a primary surplus (a budget surplus, ignoring debt repayment costs), and even boasts that the threat of leaving the eurozone has receded. Today there is no more talk about the infamous Grexit. Barroso's message didn't cheer Yiannis Mouzakis (who blogs as Prodigal Greek from Cyprus): EC president José Manuel Barroso has declared that there is light at the end of the tunnel for Greece. Speaking at the press conference with prime minister Antonis Samaras in Brussels, Barroso said that the long sacrifices suffered by the Greek people would be rewarded next year when the country finally returns to growth. Barroso also reached out to the Greek population, saying the Commission continues to "stand by" them at this time.... ...before insisting that Greece must continue to swallow its medicine by implementing the measures which have been agreed (and which some public workers are protesting about today). Associated Press's Brussels correspondent, Jurgen Baetz, has the key quotes: Heads-up: Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras is about to take part in a press conference in Brussels, with European Commission president José Manuel Barroso: US inflation data for August has been released, setting the scene for the Federal Reserve's meeting today and tomorrow. As in the UK this morning, there was a drop in the rising cost of living -- to just 1.5% annually, slightly below expectations. On a month-on-month basis, prices were just 0.1% higher. Greek doctors also started a three-day walkout today, as Associated Press explains: Greek hospital doctors have embarked on a three-day strike, joining high school teachers who walked off the job a day earlier in a week of public sector strikes protesting planned job cuts. The doctors walked off the job Tuesday, ahead of a two-day civil service strike that is expected to affect public services across the country, including schools, hospitals and some transport systems. Under government plans, 25,000 public sector employees are to be suspended this year and 15,000 must be fired in the next 15 months as part of efforts to trim the bloated public sector and meet the conditions of Greece's international bailout. The country has been depending on rescue loans from the International Monetary Fund and other European countries that use the euro currency since May 2010. Fresh anti-austerity demonstrations have been taking place in Greece today, involving social security workers and municipal police. Both groups were protesting about plans to cut thousands of public sector jobs, and force others into a 'mobility pool' on lower wages. As these photos show, social security employees demonstrated outside the Labor Ministry in Athens, and held a sit-down protest in the road. It's the second day of a five-day strike. ....and tangled with police offices as they tried to enter the building. However, there are no reports of repeats of yesterday's teargassings (after which three people were treated in hospital). Elsewhere in Athens, the municipal police officers staged a protest march that ended at the Ministry of Administrative Reform: Tomorrow, the civil servant union ADEDY begins a 48-hour strike, which will show the current depth of feeling over Greece's austerity programme. There's also plenty of speculation about what Berlusconi's video message might contain, as Open Europe analyst Vincenzo Scarpetta explains: The content of the video message remains a mystery. The latest reports in the Italian media suggest that Berlusconi may use it to attack judges, while reiterating his support for Enrico Letta’s government. But the truth is no-one really knows. Reuters also reckons Berlusconi's video message is delayed until tomorrow -- perhaps to give him a clear run at the spotlight? Sources in Berlusconi's current People of Freedom (PDL) party, which replaced Forza Italia in 2008, said the pre-recorded message would now be transmitted on Wednesday. They gave no clear reason although there was speculation the master communicator did not want to fight for air time with the successful operation to raise the wrecked Costa Concordia liner from rocks off the Tuscan coast on Tuesday. Just hearing from Italy that Silvio Berlusconi's eagerly awaited video message (see 12.19pm) won't be released until Wednesday. talian newspaper Corriere Della Sera reckons it's been postponed so he can make some last-minute tweaks to the message. If it's really held back till tomorrow, it will hit the TV screens as the Italian Senate’s Immunities Committee holds its first vote on whether to expel him from the Senate. Oh, the suspense.... It seems that more bicycles were sold than cars in Spain last year – just one sign of Europe's wider economic malaise. Wherever you live in Europe, if you've bought a new bicycle in the last year – or you've given up your car in favour of cycling or walking – we'd like to hear from you. To take part, please show us a picture of your bike via GuardianWitness and tell us why you bought it and how your life has changed as a result. We'll feature some of your stories on the Guardian business live blog. Tension is growing in Italy ahead of the release of a video message from Silvio Berlusconi. The disgraced former prime minister, facing possible imminent expulsion from the Senate, has recorded two addresses, and is expected to release the first one today. No sign of it yet, though. A Senate committee will decide tomorrow whether to boot Berlusconi out of the Senate over his tax fraud conviction. Berlusconi could retaliate by withdrawing his support its coalition. However.... there's speculation that the video message could actually be a show of support for prime minister Enrico Letta. Renato Brunetta, floor leader in the Chamber of Deputies for Berlusconi's People of Freedom Party (PDL) tweeted this morning that Berlusconi "Will make a very important announcement about Forza Italia (Go Italy), aiming to inspire everybody." Forza Italia is Berlusconi's original political vehicle, which was superceded by the PDL. This cartoon questions whether Berlusconi could possibly rise again: The big question, though, is how Berlusconi reacts if he is expelled from the Senate (which would require a vote on the floor of the Senate) As Reuters puts it: Some sources said on Tuesday that Berlusconi was considering resigning before a full Senate vote to expel him, but this could come in a second video message after the committee vote on Wednesday night. Berlusconi appears to be using the resurrection of his original Forza Italia party to try to seize back the political initiative following the damaging conviction, which has condemned him either to a year's house arrest or community service. Citigroup has stuck its neck out this morning, predicting that the FTSE 100 will hit 8,000 points by the end of next year. That would be a rise of over 20% (even putting London's house price inflation in the shade), from today's 6598 points. My colleague Nick Fletcher reports that Citi expects the FTSE will hit 7,500 by next summer -- meaning it would finally break through the 7,000 points barrier for the first time. Here's Citi's reasoning, based in part on a recovery in Europe: We stay bullish on UK and European equities over the coming 12-18 months: 1) better macro, 2) better earnings, 3) rising risk appetite. There may be better near-term entry points, but we see healthy 25% returns to the end of 2014. In Europe, we expect a GDP and earnings inflection in 2014 versus 2013. Negative GDP and earnings growth to be replaced by positive growth, in our view. More here: Citigroup forecasts FTSE 100 could reach 8000 by the end of 2014 In other economic news, rising exports have helped to widen the euro zone's trade surplus. Eurostat reported that the eurozone ran a surplus of €18.2bn in July, up from €13.9bn a year ago. Exports were 3% higher year-on-year, while imports were flat. And there's no prizes for guessing which country ran the latest trade surplus in the first half of the year. Concerning the total trade of Member States, the largest surplus was observed in Germany (+€98.0bn in January-June 2013), followed by the Netherlands (+€28.0bn), Ireland (+€18.6bn) and Italy (+€12.3bn). France (-€38.0bn) registered the largest deficit, followed by the United Kingdom (-€31.7bn) and Greece (-€9.7bn). The data's online here Interestingly,the eurozone ran a broadly flat trade balance until the crisis began (although there were large differences between member states). Once it plunged into recession, imports began to slide as the painful austerity-driven "rebalancing" began. Here's Katie Allen's news story on today's UK inflation data: UK inflation dips as rise in cost of fuel and clothing eases Some early reaction to today's UK inflation data: Jens Larsen, economist at RBC: Absent a shock in petrol or utility prices, inflation may come down quicker than the MPC (Monetary Policy Committee) thinks. David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce: The fall in inflation will ease pressure on businesses and consumers at a time when earnings growth is only around 1%, and the government is still pressing ahead with cutting the budget deficit. Our forecast remains that inflation will fall gradually over the next year, but unexpected surges in energy and food prices remain a risk. Jeremy Cook, chief economist at the foreign exchange company, World First: We are getting growth in the UK, but without huge improvements in unemployment and it seems without too many price pressures either.... The slack in the UK economy following years of weak performance will take time to improve and with that comes fairly benign price activity. Recent strength in sterling markets has also helped offset increase in oil prices that occurred during the escalation of tensions around the Syrian conflict. Unfortunately, while this will be good news for Mark Carney and the team at Threadneedle Street given the inflationary caveats to their forward guidance plan, to the man on the street, who are seeing wage increases at only 1%, this still means that life and spending decisions remain tough, and in reality, talk of a recovery remains merely talk.… Back on UK inflation, Labour’s Treasury minister Cathy Jamieson has chastised the government for allowing wages to lag behind the cost of living. Here's her response: With prices still rising much faster than wages the cost of living crisis under David Cameron continues. After three damaging years of flatlining, working people are worse off by almost £1,500 a year under this Tory-led government. But rather than helping ordinary families David Cameron is so out of touch he has given a huge tax cut to millionaires instead. We need action now to help people struggling with the rising cost of living. That's why Labour is calling for a lower 10p starting rate of tax to help millions on middle and low incomes and action to tackle soaring energy bills - not a tax cut for millionaires. Meanwhile in Germany, the ZEW index of investor confidence has risen this month, and by more than expected, driven by an improved eurozone outlook It has jumped to 49.6, up from 42 in August, in a sign that German analyst and investors are more upbeat about prospects. It's the highest reading since April 2010 (according to Reuters) Clemens Fuest, president of the ZEW thinktank, explained: The financial market experts hold the view that the German economy is still gaining momentum. In particular, the experts’ economic optimism has increased due to the improved economic outlook for the euro zone. You can read the ONS's data yourself, here: • Consumer Price Index Inflation for August • House price index for July London house prices are up 9.7% over the last 12 months.... Crucially, the rising cost of living continues to outstrip wages. Whether you take CPI (2.7%) or RPI (3.3%), inflation continues to devour the meagre salary increases doled out to Britain's workers. Wages are up by just 1% annually. Melanie Bowler, economist at Moody's Analytics, warns that wages are unlikely to catch up: Fiscal austerity, job security concerns ensuring wage demands remain restrained, and weak wage growth—public sector wages are frozen—are helping to anchor inflation expectations. The Treasury broke off from counting the takings from the Lloyds share sale to welcome today's inflation data. Here's the official response: Inflation has fallen, and is nearly half of its peak of 5.2 per cent. The economy is turning a corner, but the recovery is in its early stages and risks remain. The only way to deliver a sustained improvement in living standards is to tackle the economy’s problems head on and deliver a recovery that works for all. The Government knows that times are tough and that is why we have taken action to help with the cost of living including increasing the tax-free personal allowance, introducing tax-free childcare and freezing fuel duty and council tax. While the CPI measure of inflation fell to 2.7% last month, the Retail Prices Index (a wider measure of the cost of living) rose to 3.3%, from 3.1%. The Bank of England's job is to keep CPI close to 2% (a task which it traditionally struggles), and today's drop makes an interest rate rise less likely. But a rising RPI suggests less relief for the public. Economist Shaun Richards isn't impressed to see the RPI rising: UK house prices are still just below the peak of January 2008, according to the ONS's new data (see graph above). However, the England House Price Index is now 0.9% higher than at the previous peak in January 2008. That's not going to puncture fears of a house price bubble.... However.... the ONS is also reporting that UK house price inflation rose in July. However, while English house prices are romping ahead to a new record high, they fell back in Scotland. Again, here's the key points: In the 12 months to July 2013 UK house prices increased by 3.3%, up from a 3.1% increase in the 12 months to June 2013. House price growth remains stable across most of the UK, although prices in London are increasing faster than the UK average. The year-on-year increase reflected growth of 3.7% in England and 1.8% in Northern Ireland, offset by falls of 2.0% in Scotland and 0.7% in Wales. Here's the key points of today's UK inflation data, from the Office for National Statistics: The Consumer Prices Index (CPI) grew by 2.7% in the year to August 2013, down from 2.8% in July. The largest contributions to the fall in the rate came from the transport (particularly motor fuels and air transport) and clothing sectors. These were partially offset by an upward contribution from furniture, household equipment & maintenance. The other main inflation measures were unchanged between July and August: CPIH grew by 2.5% and RPIJ grew by 2.6%. These latest numbers continue the trend of broadly steady inflation seen since spring 2012. Breaking news: UK inflation fell last month. The Consumer Prices index was 2.7% in August, down from July's 2.8%. Details and reaction to follow.... Shares in European carmakers have fallen this morning, as investors balk at the news that sales during 2013 have been the lowest on record (see opening post for the details). Peuguet Citreon is the biggest casualty, with its shares skidding by 3.5% this morning. It had a particularly grisly August, with sales dropping by -17.3% in August 2013 versus 2012. Renault shares have fallen 1.6% this morning (its sales are down 2% in 2013) Fiat shares have dropped 0.9% (its sales are down 8.6% this year). The UK government made a profit of £60m through the sale of £3bn worth of Lloyds shares last night (see 8.07am), my colleague Jill Treanor reports: In a significant turnaround for the bailed out bank – and five years to the day since Lloyds TSB rescued HBOS to create the enlarged group – the government body tasked with selling the shares said it had reduced the taxpayer stake to 32.7% from 38.7%. Chancellor George Osborne has declared that the sale will help repair the economy - and even took his message to Twitter: Osborne later added: If you look at what has happened over the last 12 hours with Lloyds, you have investors from around the world investing in a British bank. That is a sign the British economy is turning a corner." "Five years ago the previous government forced British taxpayers to put a huge sum of money into bailing out the banks. That was a big ask of the British public. I have been determined ever since I became Chancellor to get that money back for taxpayers. European stock markets are all down this morning, as yesterday's rally runs out of steam. Spain and Italy have the biggest losses, with the IBEX and FTSE MIB indices down almost 0.5%: Earlier, Japan's Nikkei fell 93 points, or 0.65%, to 14,311. World markets rose yesterday on the prospect of the dovish Janet Yellen taking over at the Federal Reserve. She certainly looks like the front-runner. As my US colleagues Dan Roberts and Dominic Rushe wrote last night: Rebel Democrats on Monday threw their weight behind a growing campaign for Janet Yellen to take over the US Federal Reserve, as their successful revolt against White House pick Larry Summers emboldened those calling for tougher policy toward Wall Street. But while Yellen is seen as more supportive of economic stimulus than Summers, she might also take a harder line on bank regulation.... More here: Democrats push for Janet Yellen as Fed chair after Summers withdrawal Shares in Lloyds Banking Group are down 2% this morning, from 77.3p to 75.6p , following the sale of part of the UK taxpayers stake in the bank. Makes sense, given the Treasury sold its shares for 75p each. Joe Rundle, head of trading at ETX Capital, reckons Lloyds shares should be popular with investors betting on a British recovery (as its operations are mainly based in the UK): Rundle said: Many will see this as a symbol of the UK’s financial system returning to health as institutional investors snapped up the shares on offer, an indication that the market feels far more comfortable with the UK banking sectors’ prospects given the upswing we are seeing in the UK economy. Lloyds itself is a leveraged play on the UK economy for investors – if you believe in the UK recovery, Lloyds is the likely long play versus the likes of riskier banks RBS and Barclays. Also coming up today.... • We get the latest UK inflation data at 9.30am BST (10am CEST). Economists expected a slight drop in the rising cost of living, with the consumer prices index falling from 2.8% to 2.7%. • The German ZEW survey will show economic sentiment in Europe's biggest economy, at 10am BST (11am CEST) • Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras is visiting Brussels to meet with top officials, to discuss its upcoming EU presidency and its bailout package. Details are vague at this stage, as Matina Stevis of the WSJ flags up: • European stock markets are expected to drop back after yesterday's rally • The Federal Reserve will begin its monthly meeting, although we don't get its decisions until tomorrow The other big news this morning is that the UK government successfully sold part of its stake in Lloyds Banking Group overnight, beginning the process of returning the bank to the private sector. UK Financial Instruments reported that it found buyers for 6% of Lloyds' shares, raising £3.2bn. The shares were placed at 75p each, slightly over the 73.6p at which the taxpayer bought into the bank during the height of the financial crisis. It cuts the government's total stake from 38.7% to 32.7%, as reported last night. The sale feels like another milestone in the road back from the crisis, coming five years after the week in which the collapse of Lehman Brothers shook the financial world. We'll have more details shortly... Another sign of Europe's malaise... in Spain, sales of bicycles apparently overtook car sales in 2012. That's according to The Times this morning, which writes: Spaniards bought more bicycles than new cars last year as the economic crisis, which has left at least a quarter of the workforce unemployed, strengthened its grip on the country. The lure of a free means of transport led about 780,000 Spaniards to buy a bicycle last year, an increase of 4 per cent from the year before. Sales of cars fell by 31.4 per cent to 700,000. Spanish car sales are down another 3.6% so far this year, according to today's data. Today's data (which is online here), also shows that austerity continues to chew away at consumers in the European periphery. Sales in Cyprus have tumbled by 40% so far this year -- showing the impact of its bailout, and capital controls which restrict how much money they can take out from the bank. In Ireland, sales are down 7.7%, while Greek car sales fell by another 4.5% compared with the first eight months of 2012 -- a time in which the country was gripped by fears that it would crash out of the eurozone. Hyundai Europe chief executive Allan Rushforth reckons that Europe's mid-market carmakers are being crunched by market pressure. He told Reuters: What we're seeing right now in the European car industry is a squeezed middle German premium brands are coming down through the market while Hyundai is moving up (and) making life very difficult for European volume brands rooted in the mainstream. Hyundai's sales are down 2% so far this year, less than that 5% industry average. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the latest events across the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and the business world. Breaking news to start the day -- Europe's car industry has suffered another dire month as sales in its troubled automobile industry slumped to an alltime low. Eight months into the year, fewer cars have been sold than in any year since 1990, according to new data from the European Automobile Manufacturers Association. It reports that new registrations have fallen by 5.2% since January, to just 7,841,596 units across the whole of Europe. Many of Europe's big name manufactures continue to see sales slide. ACEA admitted that August (never a great month for car sales) had been particularly tough, as the "downturn prevailed across significant markets". This graph shows the damage in 2013, with sales rising in just two months (April and July). New passenger car registrations declined by 5.0% in August compared with a year ago, reversing a 5% jump in July. Demand dropped in all major markets, denting hopes that the worst was over. The UK was the only major market to post growth in August, with sales jumping by 10.9%. Otherwise, it's another dire picture - with Germany contracting by 5.5%, and Italian sales down 6.6%. French car sales suffered a double-digit decline, falling by 10.5%, while the Spanish market was rough -- tumbling by 18.3%. Some European manufacturers have had a year to forget. • Peugeot Citreon's sales are down by 12.3% so far this year. • Fiat are down 8.6% • Volkswagen sales have dropped by 4.6% Jaguar Land Rover, though, bucks the trend with a +10.0% rise in sales between January and August. Not a great start to the day, and a cautionary tale to those who reckon Europe's economic woes are over. Reaction to follow, along with other details of the day ahead....
